Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Novel Bioprocess for Lipid Production from Industrial Byproducts
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase II Project is to produce economically the next generation of sustainable, renewable, clean burning, high energy density, transportation biofuels. The proposed technology once successfully developed will enable existing biofuel producers to reduce their costs while increasing the value and diversity of their byproducts. It will convert their industrial waste products into tailored fatty acids suitable for biodiesel. The technology will be compatible with and complementary to cellulosic ethanol producers, and it could potentially double the amount of biodiesel produced in the U.S. today. The 227 domestic ethanol plants range in size from less than 50 to more than 150 million gallons, and they have a total annual capacity of 15 billion gallons. Every gallon of ethanol also yields 1.9 pounds of soluble organics that must be evaporated or disposed. Xylome?s technology has the potential to convert half of this stream into biodiesel and to expand biodiesel production further with cellulosic feedstocks. By converting a larger fraction of the soluble cellulosic and hemicellulosic sugars along with fermentation byproducts, Xylome will increase the efficiency of existing ethanol plants and increase biofuel production.

The objectives of this Phase II research are to increase the rates of production, modification and release of fatty acids from non-conventional lipogenic yeast. Fatty acids have much higher energy density than ethanol, but similar specific energy yields. Fermentation of organics to lipids can potentially occur with efficiencies equivalent to ethanol production. Lipids normally accumulate under nitrogen limiting conditions after replication has stopped. They are not excreted from the cells so recovery does not require distillation. In Phase I, Xylome scientists identified and over expressed genes that increase lipid accumulation by 1.2- to 2-fold under high nitrogen conditions. In Phase II, they will use mating, selection, screening and evolutionary adaptation to combine the best of these modifications. Xylome scientists have also targeted additional genes to modify and release fatty acids from the cell. Xylome plans to optimize lipid production both from a cellular level with metabolic engineering and from an engineering perspective through bioprocess design and cultivation conditions. Xylome will also engineer cells to use rapidly the complex mixture of soluble oligosaccharides, hemicellulosic sugars and fermentation byproducts. By applying advanced molecular techniques and synthetic biology, Xylome will open up new opportunities for sustainable biofuel production.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Engineered oils from agricultural byproducts

The future of our planet depends upon developing sustainable means for supplying food, materials and energy while reducing carbon emissions, to which agriculture contributes significantly. Xylome’s innovative technologies developed under this NSF-SBIR grant can capture value from agricultural byproducts and convert them into oils that are suitable for food, fuels and consumer products.

Xylome’s NSF Small business Innovative Research (SBIR) grant allowed development and application of tools for engineering the genome of Lipomyces starkeyi, one of the most lipogenic yeasts known. It also facilitated the identification of key genes, which when overexpressed, enable L. starkeyi to produce very high levels of oil from a range of industrial substrates.

These genetic technologies enabled Xylome scientists to understand how to increase L. starkeyi’s capacity for lipid production, alter its lipid profile and to create higher value products. Depending on the feedstock, fermentation and processing technology, engineered strains of L. starkeyi can be used to make biodiesel precursors, a substitute for palm oil, personal care products or a high omega-3 fatty acid feed for aquaculture.

L. starkeyi is a soil yeast that has been studied for over 65 years. It can be found as a normal skin microflora and has never been associated with any infection or pathology. Starting by sequencing its genome and developing the first transformation system for this yeast, Xylome scientists created a set of synthetic selectable markers that would allow for the introduction of genes through targeted and random integration.

Xylome scientists developed highly productive strains along with fermentation technologies and down-stream oil recovery processes that have led to collaboration with major fuel ethanol producers for scale-up and commercialization. From the outset, one of Xylome’s key objectives was to focus on using byproduct organics from the fuel ethanol industry. In North America, ethanol plants generate more than 300,000 tons of residual organics while producing ethanol. Xylome targeted these low-value organics, which pose a disposal problem, for conversion into biodiesel feedstocks. Our scientists tested more than 30 genes in various combinations to determine which were most effective in increasing lipid production from the principal organic constituents and developed cultivation techniques that would make the oils rapidly at high concentrations.

In the process they had to overcome numerous barriers: How to screen for strains that are highly productive when cultivated on crude industrial substrates? How to maximize lipid production from poorly utilized carbon sources? How to recover oil from the cells after it is formed? Addressing these problems required working closely with industrial ethanol producers to understand the existing plant processes, production streams, markets and challenges.

While the path to a new industrial fermentation process for renewable oils is difficult, it also has the potential to double the production of vegetable oils in the U.S. without cultivating or harvesting any additional grain. By creating a new palm-oil substitute, Xylome’s technology could spare the destruction of tropical rain forests, and the foundational technologies could lead to the development of new sources of poly-unsaturated fatty acids to use in aquaculture.

Xylome has protected its strain and process technologies by filing several patents, and collaborating with industrial ethanol producers to scale-up its process.


Last Modified: 01/17/2020
Modified by: Thomas W Jeffries
